## ABOUT THIS REPORT

This report describes our performance in Colombia and Central America from January 1st to December 31st, 2022.

This report complies with the guidelines issued by the Financial Superintendence of Colombia (SFC) pursuant to Decree 151 issued in 2021 and the External Circular 012 issued in 2022 which regulates it.

Furthermore, this report was prepared based on the reference framework set forth in the methodology and guidelines established by the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) standard for the preparation of sustainability reports, in line with the company's sustainable management approach to material issues and stakeholder relations. This report was verified by an independent third party, who assessed that the contents herein are in compliance with the standard.

Sustainability stands at the core of Davivienda's business strategy. Therefore, we voluntarily adhered to the 10 Principles of the Global Compact and are committed to contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) defined by the United Nations, as well as our voluntary compliance with reporting

<!-- image -->

frameworks to properly disclose our management of corporate governance, environmental and social issues, such as the Green Protocol, the Carbon Footprint Disclosure Project (CDP), the Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI) and the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD). Moreover, in 2022 our work was recognized by being featured in the Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI) for the integrated Latin American Market (MILA) yet again.

In addition to the message from our CEO and a summary of key facts and figures regarding our performance on material issues, we include a description of the enablers of our business: human talent, risk management, corporate governance and technology, all framed within an overview of the economic outlook of the countries in which we operate. This document consolidates our financial, environmental and social performance in a year marked by local and international uncertainty and volatility, both from an economic and political perspective.

Finally, we have included a set of chapters and appendices supplementing the information and formi an integral part of this report, such as the Consolidated and Individual Financial Statements, and the TCFD report.

## MESSAGE FROM THE CEO

On our 50th anniversary, we reaffirm our commitment to fulfill our higher purpose: enriching life with integrity. Today we have our sights aimed towards the future we want to build alongside our stakeholders. A future in which we will continue taking our transformation capacity to even more people and businesses in order to generate progress in the places where we operate, while taking care of the planet and guaranteeing sustainable business growth, leveraged in technology and our characteristic digital essence.

2022 was a year with a challenging and volatile global and regional economic environment, in which we experienced the main consequences of post-pandemic times: there were interruptions in global supply chains and decelerations in the world's most important economies. Additionally, we observed rapidly increasing inflation levels, which led central banks to toughen their monetary policies, increasing interest rates in an accelerated manner. This situation generated direct impacts in our economies, especially in resource availability for families and businesses.

In Colombia, the annual inflation closed at 13.12%, reaching the highest level reported in the last 23 years, while the Central Bank raised its monetary policy rate by 900 basis points throughout the year, taking it to 12% in December, which is a level not seen since 1999. Uncertainty from an economic standpoint, together with the elections, and the following signals of potential reforms regarding different aspects, were reflected in the market's behavior, impacting devaluation levels for the local currency, as well as participation, inflows and outflows of foreign capital.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

This scenario inevitably had an effect on our customers, the business and our financial results. In this sense, our profits for the year closed at COP/uni00A01.62 trillion, which represented a return on average equity of 10.74%, which was impacted by higher funding costs and provision expenses.

Nevertheless, this macroeconomic environment was an opportunity to continue creating innovative solutions, maintaining our leadership in the financial sector in Colombia and Central America, and advancing in all of our strategic pillars, consolidating ourselves as a multilatin, digital and sustainable organization. This way, we connected with new communities and reached 21.8/uni00A0million customers, more than 2 times the amount we had at the end of 2018.

We remain as key actors in Colombia and Central America with market shares of 16.2% 1 and 9.5% 2 , respectively. Our capital and funding management kept leveraging business growth, allowing our consolidated gross loan portfolio to grow by 22.1% over the year, closing at COP/uni00A0144.8 trillion, out of which 10% currently funds sustainable projects. Our total capital adequacy ratio closed at 16.29%, which establishes us as one of the best capitalized banks in the country on a consolidated basis.

<!-- image -->

## 21.8 million customers

More than two times 2018's customer base, by connecting with new communities throughout the year.

We are aware that 2023 will also be a challenging year, and are prepared to face it. We will work to make our operation more efficient and to offer our customers a world class service, supporting them in a better way with self management solutions that will allow us to be more productive. We will focus our efforts on actively managing our loan portfolio, we will continue participating in the ecosystems where our customers are and will continuously seek to increase our share in the transactional world, generating better results for our shareholders and investors.

## THE WORLD IS OUR HOME

We are going through a changing environment, which calls for us to reinforce our participation in the financial world's transformation towards a more prosperous, inclusive and clean world. Today we ratify that more than having a sustainability strategy, our strategy is sustainable. We are within the top 15% of the most sustainable companies in the financial sector at a global level in S&P Global's Sustainability Yearbook, and were included for a ninth consecutive year in the S&P Global's Dow Jones Sustainability Index.

## Consolidated Gross Loans Growth: 22.1%.

We seek to make the world our home by managing our business in a sustainable way. We are aware of our role as a driver for economic development by mobilizing resources. This is why we put forward actions that from a business and sustainable financing perspective mitigate climate change and generate positive impacts in society. We finance projects with a social and environmental purpose, with business lines designed specifically for sustainable housing, low income housing, women led SMEs, electric and hybrid vehicle purchases, among others. Our sustainable loan portfolio reached COP/uni00A014.8 trillion at the end of 2022, growing by 26.5% compared to 2021.

Taking this into account and being aware of our actions, we adhered to the Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI) in order to contribute to the consolidation of a more sustainable financial system, incorporating more social and environmental factors in both our and our client's investment decisions.

Posed with the climate change challenge, we actively contributed to the transition towards a resilient and low carbon economy. From our business, we focused on measuring indirect emissions and evaluating climate change risks associated with our loan portfolios. In order to leverage this labor, we adhered to the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF) and incorporated the PACTA (Paris Agreement Capital Transition Assessment) methodology, aiming to guarantee our contribution with Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement. Regarding direct emissions, we actively managed greenhouse gas emissions in our operations, which

allowed us to receive the Carbon Neutral Verification for Colombia and Central America by ICONTEC, which also recognized us as the first entity in Latin America to receive the renewable energy seal.

In terms of socioeconomic development, we work together with Grupo Bolivar's other companies and other strategic allies to boost social impact ecosystems, capable of promoting the financial inclusion and literacy of communities. Our financial literacy program has been recognized by the Financial Superintendency of Colombia (SFC) for its quality, pertinence and suitability to eliminate access barriers to the banking system and for promoting healthy financial habits. In this way, we have reached diverse population segments such as farmers markets, artisans, informal vendors, cacao, coffee and plantain producers, among other communities by giving them access to credit, transactional, saving and payment solutions, as well as offering them educational tools that leverage their businesses. In total, we reached 104 farmers markets, 66 thousand informal vendors, 23 thousand artisans and 34 thousand producers, capturing around 13.5/uni00A0million transactions with a business model based on trust, the power to break cultural barriers, and the capacity of transforming cash usage and informal financing habits.

We work everyday to make Davivienda a more diverse, equitable and inclusive place, in which we encourage empathy and innovation. We are proud that, on average, 30% of our boards of directors are conformed by women, and 42% of our management positions are occupied by women.

## WE ARE MORE THAN A BANK

In Davivienda we go further than offering financial products and services. We connect with the ecosystems where our customers live in order to satisfy their needs easier with novel digital solutions and a high level of service. Additionally, we are working to involve our allies in the development of financial experiences, complementing our service offering so our customers can find what they need in Davivienda.

Thanks to the digital skills we have developed throughout the years, we supported 170 thousand small business and entrepreneurs through initiatives available on our apps such as Mi Negocio and Mi Comercio, which allow them to reach more people easily, as well as supporting their growth with payment solutions, catalog creation, inventory management, among others.

We keep demonstrating Daviplata's potential for reaching more population segments, reaching 15.6/uni00A0million customers at the end of the year and covering 99% 3 of Colombia's territory. This Neobank for everyone is our financial inclusion flagship, by being the only financial product of 4.1/uni00A0million Colombians.

Aligned with our innovative and digital essence, we tested new technologies in order to be at the forefront of banking. In this sense, together with IDB Invest we issued the first blockchain bond in Latin America within the regulatory sandbox in Colombia. This technology seeks to generate a more transparent, agile and safe market, reducing the costs and complexity of issuances, as well as allowing the entrance of more market participants and purveying elements to evolve regulation regarding these types of technologies.

## FOR AN EXCITING FUTURE

As a result of strengthening our innovation abilities, we put Efecto i at the service of the whole country. This is an initiative oriented towards promoting projects that generate a positive impact in society, strengthening available tools so that young entrepreneurs can leverage their businesses with Grupo Bolivar's innovation methodology.

We have been learning and growing for 50 years. I would like to thank all our employees for their dedication, our shareholders for their trust, our suppliers for being key allies, and our other stakeholders for their support along the way. In 2023, we will continue working in our bank transformation, exploring new technologies, and building more and better solutions that get us closer to the new generations.

We are enthusiastic about the roadmap we have set forth to take our service to another level and stand closer to our customers, demonstrating Davivienda's ability to remain as the organization you have believed in for the past 50 years.

## RATING AGENCIES

S&P Dow Jones Indexes: Over the past 9 years we have been invited to participate in this corporate sustainability global evaluation due to our commitment to economic, environmental and social matters. Consequently, we have been included in the emerging markets list of the MILA Pacific Alliance version of this index, ranking as one of the best financial institutions in this category. S&P Global honored us for the sixth consecutive year in the Sustainability Yearbook, as a company among the 15% of companies in the industry with the best sustainability practices in the world.

CDP Disclosure Insight Action: We have adhered to the Carbon Disclosure Project for 8 consecutive years, measuring environmental sustainability factors and adopting best practices to manage them.

## REPORTING FRAMEWORKS

Global Reporting Initiative (GRI): Davivienda adopted this sustainability management standards methodology to plan, measure, and assess our sustainable performance indicators as a best practice to comply with international standards.

Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF): This standard helps us better measure emissions derived from our financing activities in an effort to properly assess transition risks associated with climate change, set targets in line with the Paris Agreement, and pursue effective strategies to decarbonize the economy.

## Paris Agreement Capital Transition Assessment (Pacta):

Davivienda has adopted the Pacta methodology for scenario analyses pertaining emissions derived from our corporate portfolio financing activities, aiming at steering our strategy towards a positive climate impact.

Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): Our strategy is aligned with the goals and objectives established by the United Nations (UN), as we contribute to achieving SDGs by appropriately managing material issues, risks, and opportunities. Accordingly, we have prioritized 6 goals and 17 targets, with which we seek the development of people, the prosperity in the nations we serve, and global wellbeing.

United by SDGs: We are actively involved in measuring how the Colombian business sector contributes to the achievement of the SDGs, through this initiative supported by Pacto Global Red Colombia and Fundación Bolívar Davivienda, as part of our commitment to promoting sustainable development and transparency across the industry.

## Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD):

We assess, measure, prioritize, and manage opportunities and risks associated with climate change following the recommendations provided by this working group, and by adopting best practices to minimize negative impacts.

Regarding seasonal income, it is important to note that some of the income may be related to the year-end season, when there is greater consumption and, therefore, greater demand for credit. In addition, it is common that during certain months of the year, such as July and December, the flow of remittances received by customers increases, which translates into higher income from financial services. As for corporate banking, the tourism and foreign trade sector can also generate seasonal income, especially during periods of high demand.

## 91% of our customers in Colombia are digital

In 2022, 57% of our monetary transactions and 60% of our sales were conducted through digital channels.

Regarding cyclical income in our bank, it is possible that it is linked to the country's economic situation. For example, during periods of economic growth, it is common for loan demand to increase, which translates into higher interest income. On the other hand, in times of economic uncertainty, clients may choose to save more and borrow less, which could reduce the bank's income. In addition, cyclical income may also be related to developments in capital markets and investment levels.

Finally, regarding occasional income, it is important to mention that this can come from various sources, such as the sale of non-strategic assets or the recovery of bad loans. These revenues can occur at any time and are not subject to a specific period of the year or market fluctuations. The sale of non-strategic assets may be related to our asset management strategy, while the recovery of bad loans may be linked to the effectiveness of our debt recovery processes or specific decisions to sell written-off loans.

In terms of our market position, we are the second largest credit institution operating in the Colombian financial system in terms of assets, gross loans, and deposits.

## WEALTH MANAGEMENT

Our Wealth Management business is managed by Fiduciaria Davivienda S.A. and Corredores Davivienda S.A.. These companies are focused on providing a diversified range of products to offer our customers various investment options tailored to their needs and risk profiles. Therefore, we constantly monitor the market and manage different portfolios, offering our customers the best returns by optimizing their risk exposure according to their different profiles.

-   Fiduciaria Davivienda S.A. was established to broaden and diversify the portfolio of services o/ffered by Grupo Empresarial Bolivar by designing products in investment funds and structured trusts; today it is positioned among the leading companies in the trust business in Colombia. The trust company complements its value o/ffer to our clients with a broad portfolio of products underpinned by the know-how and expertise of its executives.
-   Corredores Davivienda S.A. complements our investment services by o/ffering our clients brokerage, administrative, and custody services for equity and /fixed income securities, including stocks, bonds, term deposits, and TIPS (securitization securities). Our main clients include individuals, SMEs, corporations, and government entities.

In seasonal terms of the trust business, during the first months of the year there are usually higher investment flows and

there is an increase in demand for structured trust services, due to the execution of construction, infrastructure and other investment projects that start at this time of the year. For its part, in the brokerage business it has been observed that the last quarter of the year usually presents a higher volume of stock market transactions, since many companies and investment funds try to close their positions before the end of the year.

Regarding the cyclicality of the businesses, it can be said that the investment trends of clients and the activity of the stock market can vary depending on economic and political cycles. In periods of economic or political instability, investors tend to be more cautious and may reduce their exposure to the stock market, resulting in decreased demand for trust and brokerage services.

2022 posed major challenges for our clients investment portfolios. The war in Ukraine, rising global inflation, and the subsequent response by central banks caused turmoil in the markets and a strong appreciation of the US dollar. Additionally, the political climate in Colombia and the tax reform proposed by the new government gave as a result a high volatility in capital market asset prices, which prompted many investors to keep a portion of their funds in traditional bank deposits, fixedincome products and dollar-denominated products.

## PHYSICAL RISKS

In 2022, we deepened the identification of physical risks with the greatest potential impact by credit segments and productive sectors, especially in the territories where we identified a significant change in future climate scenarios.

In order to refine our scenario analysis for physical risks in 2022, we focused on integrating, through a pilot exercise, the information from WorldClim 19 , which we used to generate analysis layers for Colombia. These results allowed us to identify and prioritize the regions with the greatest change in temperature and precipitation variables, taking as a reference the historical average values in Colombia.

## TRANSITION RISKS

Regarding Transition Risks, we strengthened the identification and measurement of our total portfolio's exposure to transition risks, with quarterly exercises to calibrate the prioritization of carbon-intensive sectors: oil, coal, thermoelectric power, gas, cement, iron, steel and transportation. We also extended this methodology to the evaluation of the investment portfolio.

We deepened our knowledge of the economic activities of customers classified in these sectors, achieving greater support to promote the generation of knowledge, decarbonization and Net Zero commitments, in order to have specific reduction plans for each customer by 2030.

In the scenario analysis for transition risks, we applied the PACTA methodology, which evaluates the alignment of a portfolio with different climate scenarios based on prospective capacity and production metrics of carbonintensive customers. This methodology integrates global and regional climate scenarios through which the different production trajectories of the included sectors can be analyzed.

## FINANCED EMISSIONS MEASUREMENT

At the end of 2022 we joined PCAF (Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials) with the objective of having a globally recognized methodology for measuring the carbon emissions we finance or invest in, considering that these may be the most significant part of the emissions inventory and thus complete the measurement of our carbon footprint. Measuring financed emissions is key to

setting climate action targets, managing better and aligning with the Paris Agreement. Current target setting initiatives, such as Science Based Targets, rely on baseline calculation for implementation.

The measurement of financed emissions is performed by applying the PCAF Scope 3 Category 15 methodology to our commercial portfolio at the end of 2021, which we established as the base year. This measurement is one of the inputs for the development of our active relationship or engagement strategy with our customers.

## Environmental and Social Risk Management System - SARAS

To ensure that ESG (environmental, social, economic and corporate governance) sustainability criteria are fully embedded into our risk management system, we have implemented the Environmental and Social Risk Management System (SARAS). This system is built into our underwriting processes for loan applications submitted by our corporate and construction clients to develop environmentally sensitive projects or activities. It has allowed us to identify potential risks and to integrate eligibility criteria when assessing investment decisions and managing strategic vendors.

The Environmental and Social Risk Department of the Credit Risk VP manages the SARAS and reports, when applicable, to the Corporate Risk Committee, the Corporate Governance and Sustainability Committee, and the Credit Risk and Investment Committees.

The SARAS methodology comprises policies, processes, and procedures aimed at identifying, assessing, and managing risks. Furthermore, its scope is well-defined, based on amounts, terms, sensitive activities, and local regulations, when required by underwriting. Moreover, it is aligned with IFC's performance standards and norms and includes a list of excluded/restricted activities for financing.

For large infrastructure projects, SARAS-based underwriting contemplates the elements outlined in the Equator Principles methodological framework, including due diligence by an independent advisor. The following issues are assessed:

Similarly, this assessment is conducted on marketable assets, and the results are disclosed to customers for decisionmaking purposes. Responsible Investment in relation to the impact they have on investments in environmental, social and corporate governance issues.

Embedding ESG factors in an investment decision making process requires an analysis of quantitative and qualitative elements, based on an internal checklist that addresses environmental, climate change, labor, human rights and sustainability issues. Therefore, the sustainability evaluation of each dimension encompasses a range of aspects that weigh differently the companies of the real sector and the financial sector, leading to a final score per company that enables the Bank to categorize issuers in various categories. These results are shared with authorized decision-making bodies to select the issuers eligible for the investment portfolios.

Davivienda uses a heatmap to monitor how portfolios are structured. This provides the Bank with an overview of the status of the portfolio according to internally defined ESG rating criteria. As of December 2022, approximately 89% of Banco Davivienda's Investment Portfolio issuers ranked at 'outstanding' and 'acceptable' levels. The evaluation was conducted based on data gathered from the 2021 management or sustainability reports published by issuers or on direct information from the issuers that answered the survey.

## Costa Rica

We continued to work on our eco-efficiency strategy, and achieved a reduction in water and energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the year 2022. Likewise, with the support of our strategic allies, we improved the adequate waste handling and management in our operations, and we were able to achieve the following results.

-   We were able to reduce breakdowns associated with refrigerant gas leaks in air conditioning equipment by 30%.
-   We implemented a real-time monitoring system for water and energy consumption. This system allowed us to immediately address and /fix leaks and changes in consumption.
-   We signed an agreement with the company Huella Colectiva for the reuse of the material of T-shirts with outdated logos or no longer in use: we delivered 27 kg of material for the manufacture of new items using those fabrics.
-   We were able to increase by 35% the scope of facilities that manage their recycling through partnerships with waste managers.

<!-- image -->

## Less is more

Less water, less energy and lower GHG emissions in our operation are more eco-e/fficient.

-   We were able to increase the installation of e/fficient lighting in 65% of all our facilities. We replaced 90 /fluorescent lamps with 75 LED lights in the Torre Davivienda Building, Escazu.
-   We maintained the bus service from downtown (San José) to the main administrative o/ffices (Torre Davivienda, Escazu). This allowed us to reduce our carbon footprint by stopping the use of private transportation by our employees.
-   We were able to o/ffset 100% of our emissions during the year 2021 through the GalileaAmé Forest Conservation project and the SK Carbon project, located in Colombia.

In 2022, we interacted with 2,000 suppliers, 94.7% had legal representation in Colombia (1,894 of them) and the remaining 5.3% (106) were foreign companies. Those in Colombia accounted for 87.1% of the total payments.

We share our essence with our allies by implementing a development and recognition strategy that we call the 'Inspira Awards' . In 2022 we had the second rendition of these awards, with the intention of breaking paradigms, redesigning experiences and transforming processes. On this occasion, more than 100 initiatives were submitted by our suppliers and, for the first time, we had the participation of members from Honduras, El Salvador, Panama and Costa Rica in the categories of Digital Transformation, Process Efficiency and Sustainability. For Colombia, we included a new category called 'Partners of the Productive Assets Unit' , designed for suppliers that have designed business modernization projects for their clients in sectors such as transportation, commerce, and industry.

With this initiative we want to ensure excellent relationships and generate added value for those suppliers, that we consider strategic allies more than mere suppliers, expanding their business and market possibilities thanks to our linkage strategy.

We are closer to our suppliers with the implementation of a new registration scheme to streamline the process by updating

our management platform. All linked suppliers are subject to the provisions defined by Davivienda, in which we promote the transparency and objectivity of all their transactions. The supplier linkage policies can be found published on the Davivienda supplier site at the link: www.proveedores.davivienda.com in the section Relacionamiento / in the 'Políticas de Vinculación' chapter that governs suppliers.

Therefore, we take into account, among others, the incorporation of environmental, social and economic criteria in the procurement of goods or services provided to the Bank by third parties. These criteria are based on the Asobancaria Financial System Sustainable Purchasing Management Guide. The goods and services prioritized for making sustainable purchases include IT equipment, electrical appliances, paper supplies, lighting supplies, security services, housekeeping and catering services. We evaluate the environmental and social risk management of strategic suppliers with the probability of greater to lesser environmental or social impact, respectively.

The Supply Chain Risk Management methodology allows us to keep our supply chain strategy aligned. As part of this methodology, we apply the SARAS assessment to the Bank's suppliers that are deemed to be strategic. As a result of the assessment, we demonstrate the commitment of our suppliers to comply with the applicable environmental and social standards, adequate management to mitigate possible environmental and social impacts, and the implementation of good practices for the use of resources. In 2022, we evaluated 131 suppliers, of which 38% were classified in environmental and social risk category B (medium) and 62% in category C (low).

## GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE

Our organizational structure is designed to respond to business development needs and adequate risk management. Given this, we have the following risk management bodies:

##   Board of Directors

They are the main risk managers at the Bank and Subsidiaries. These evaluate the risks associated with the business and support the work of the control bodies on issues related to risk management, within the regulatory parameters. They de/fine risk policies and risk appetite, and are responsible for ensuring that they are met.

##   Audit Committee

Supervises the activities of internal auditing and /fiscal auditing regarding the evaluation of the methodology and implementation of the risk management model and the internal control system of the Bank. It issues recommendations on risk management carried out by the di/fferent risk committees.

##   Compliance Committee

It monitors and validates the implementation and execution of the Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing Risk Prevention management program, in accordance with the guidelines given by the Senior Management of the Bank and Subsidiaries, in accordance with regulations and best market practices.

##   Corporate Risk Committee

It is a support body of the Board of Directors, in charge of ensuring the operation of the corporate risk management system ( Enterprise Risk Management - ERM) of the Bank and its subsidiaries.

##   Chairmanship Committee

Based on the guidelines and approvals of the Board of Directors for the formulation of the Strategic Plan by the President of the Bank, the President's Committee becomes a support body for monitoring and due compliance with the strategy.

##   Risk Speci/fic Committees

## Credit risk

Its function is to comprehensively assess the strategic, technical and operational risk associated with the credit cycle. Likewise, it supports the management of transversal risks derived from the processes associated with the business: operational risks, fraud, technology, asset and liability management, compliance and internal control as well as environmental, social and climate change risks.

Credit risk is defined as the possibility that a borrower or counterparty does not comply with its obligations in accordance with the agreed terms, negatively affecting the value of the Bank's portfolio. This risk is mitigated through the due diversification of the portfolios in economic sectors and types of portfolio, the use of guarantees in some types of credits and through the parameters defined in the approval of the risks.

The objective of credit risk management is to maximize the Bank's profitability, adjusting to the desired risk levels. This objective is achieved by maintaining expected loss levels within acceptable parameters, without ignoring other uncertainty phenomena that may affect the portfolio's result.

Credit risk management is a logical and systematic process, which based on the context of the processes associated with the credit cycle and the stages described above, enables the Bank to identify, analyze, evaluate, control, monitor and communicate the risks associated with the lines of business, products, services and markets covered by the Bank's credit business plan, searching for improvement opportunities across all processes, and seeking to prevent or mitigate both

credit and operating losses associated with the credit cycle. This entails a risk management cycle by stages as follows:

## 1. Identi/fication

Stage that allows determining the risks (current and potential) inherent to the activities that are being carried out, or that are planned to be carried out, according to the de/finitions of the Bank's strategic plan or in compliance with current regulations that apply to the credit cycle. This stage must be completed for the implementation of changes in the business plan, entry into new markets, channels, products and/or services.

## 2. Measurement

Stage that allows quantifying and/or evaluating exposure to credit and operational risks associated with all stages of the credit cycle. It also addresses the impact and consequence when it takes place. Risk quanti/fication includes the following factors:

-   Likelihood: Quanti/fication of likelihood of default of the di/fferent segments as well as situations and uncertainty shocks that may modify them.
-   Risk Impact: Quanti/fication of the magnitude of the losses taking into account not only the likelihood of default but also the exposure and loss given the default to quantify the expected and/or incurred loss and its impact on the bank's results.
-   Velocity: Measurement of the moment in which the impact of the risk begins to materialize after the occurrence of the risk.
-   Duration : Persistence of the event of default on the results of the bank.

<!-- image -->

## 3. Control

During this stage, the mechanisms tending to mitigate and manage the materialization of the risks associated with the credit cycle must be established. These mechanisms refer to the policies, procedures and methodologies associated with the credit cycle: origination, deepening and recovery. It also includes the operational controls to ensure that they are duly implemented. The controls should make it possible to know the degree of compliance with the established regulatory thresholds and/or limits, as well as to have updated, reliable, timely and complete information for decision making.

## 4. Monitoring

Carry out permanent and e/ffective monitoring of risks sources in the credit cycle, deviations from limits and/or thresholds, the e/ffectiveness of the controls implemented and the possible impact of the materialization of risks. Such deviations are detected through portfolio monitoring, and then they are corrected by the appropriate government agencies.

## Liquidity risk

Liquidity risk is the likelihood of not being able to fully meet, in a timely and efficient manner, expected and unexpected cash flows, current and future, without affecting the course of daily operations or the financial condition of the organization. This contingency likelihood (funding liquidity risk) is evidenced in the insufficiency of available liquid assets and/or in the need to assume unusual funding costs. In turn, the capability of the organizations to generate or unwind financial positions at market prices is limited either because there is no adequate market depth or because of drastic changes in rates and prices (market liquidity risk). Similarly, for businesses that are funded through deposits, liquidity risk includes the capability to generate a stable long-term funding structure in order to maintain non-liquid assets, in accordance with the business strategy, and to be able to meet unanticipated stress situations.

Liquidity risk management in Davivienda is governed by the following strategic principles:

-   Permanent availability of high-quality liquid assets, in accordance with the balance sheet structure and risk appetite.
-   Perform prospective management, in which future contractual and non-contractual needs are estimated at various time horizons and under various scenarios, to always ensure the su/fficiency of liquid assets.
-   The balance sheet self-su/fficiency of Davivienda and of each one of its Subsidiaries must prevail in case of a liquidity crisis.
-   The availability of liquid assets should not be overestimated; that is, the level of liquidity of the assets that make up the reserves must be constantly evaluated and changes must be anticipated.
-   Mitigate reputational risk, so that we have the capacity to deal with adverse situations with our own resources without compromising compliance with current regulations and we can reduce the probability of requiring temporary support from government agencies.

The methodologies used to estimate liquidity risk, for short-term purposes, consist in calculating the cash flows of active, passive and off-balance sheet positions in different periods of time, allowing permanent monitoring of the gap of liquidity. For long-term management, the methodologies focus on the analysis of funding sources, their composition at the segment and product level,

and the characterization of assets and liabilities that do not have defined permanence conditions.

This occurred as a consequence of the reactivation of portfolio growth and the difficulty in accessing long-term funding in a context of high uncertainty, due to a contractionary monetary policy and the strong competition among organizations for resources due to the implementation of the CFEN 28 in Colombia.

## Fraud risk

Fraud Risk is classified as any illegal act whose characteristics may be deceit, concealment or violation of trust and whose objective is the appropriation of money, goods, services and/or individual advantages or benefits. It has been managed by Banco Davivienda through the Fraud risk management system (Sarfra, for its acronym in Spanish) in compliance with the regulatory framework of the Operational Risk Management system (Saro).

These reports of expenses due to the occurrence are implicit in the management of Operational Risk and are presented to the Cybersecurity and Transactional Fraud Prevention Committee for decision-making that protects the organization, our clients, shareholders and other interested parties in the search for balance between the level of fraud to be prevented and the impact on the client and the business.

## Risk of non-compliance with regulations

This is the risk of imposition of legal sanctions and/or deterioration of the Bank's reputation, derived from non-compliance with an external regulation (issued by a competent authority) or internal policy. To mitigate the risk of non-compliance with regulations, the Bank has the following three lines of defense:

-   First Line of Defense: The business, operations, and commercial areas, among others, are responsible for mitigating the risk of regulatory non-compliance in the /first line by i. knowing the internal and external regulations that impact the processes under their responsibility; and, ii. executing and ensuring the operational e/ffectiveness of the controls established, to guarantee compliance with the corresponding regulations.
-   Second Line of Defense: This is made up of the organization's risk areas, which are responsible for monitoring, in the second line, the execution and supervision of the controls that mitigate the risk of non-compliance with regulations.

<!-- image -->

Last layer of shielding of the second line of defense: The Regulatory Compliance Function is the last layer of shielding of the second line of defense, which is in charge of managing the Regulatory Non-Compliance Risk Management System, which consists of the following stages:

## Stage I, identification

this is the stage in which the external regulations and internal policies applicable to Davivienda are identified.

## Stage II, evaluation and measurement

this is the stage in which the impact of the risk of noncompliance with regulations is evaluated and measured, in case it materializes.

## Stage III, control

this is the stage in which the operational effectiveness of the controls defined by the first line of defense, through which the risk of non-compliance with regulations is mitigated, is reviewed.

## Stage IV, monitoring

this is the stage in which the action plans aimed at mitigating the risk of non-compliance with regulations are monitored until they have been completed and the risk has been duly mitigated.

-   Third line of defense: it is composed of the Internal Audit.

## EMERGING RISKS

Comprehensive Risk Management includes the review of the risk management processes and the allocation of resources to ensure that emerging risks are correctly identified, assessed, and controlled from the strategic management to day-to-day processes at all levels of the organization.

At Davivienda we continually review the conditions of the environment in order to identify changes that may affect the objectives and the strategy of the business. We then implement the necessary adjustments to adapt to changes in our environment.

Based on the organization's strategy and objectives, the Senior Management has identified 4 emerging risks that we have been monitored and controlled:

## Geopolitical risk

It is related to the political, economic, and social uncertainty caused by large-scale events at local, regional, or global levels. These include international conflicts, deglobalization, political decisions at the local and international level, and social events that may affect the economic stability of countries, among others. They may have an effect on Colombia and may impact its macroeconomic variables, especially export earnings, capital flows and foreign remittances. The Bank would be affected by the deterioration of the portfolio caused by the lack of ability to pay financial obligations and the savings and investment capacity of our customers.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

The risks associated with deglobalization that started in the middle of the last decade, movements such as Brexit (2016) and the trade war between the US and China (2018-2019), have sought to reverse global integration. The COVID-19 pandemic and Russian invasion of Ukraine have had a strong impact on the supply chain, such as food, energy and microprocessors. This has accelerated the process of reorganization of the trading blocs.

This type of situation raises questions as to how strong the fragmentation of trade, services, investment and migration channels will become, and whether new isolated power blocs will be created in the physical and virtual worlds. There are also economic impacts in terms of increased costs of goods produced, as purchases are no longer made from the most efficient global suppliers, and there are negative effects of the absence of international cooperation on the control of the effects of climate change, cyber-attacks and transnational crime. The concentration of countries on solving their own problems may also result in a decrease in international solidarity towards the poorest countries.

In 2023, a slowdown in global economic growth is expected, and some countries are even talking about recession, due to the possible continuation of contractive monetary measures by many central banks in their eagerness to contain record levels of inflation. Also, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine continues to exert pressure on international supply.

In this context, and despite the risk of recession in several developed countries, particularly the United States, the disinflation of the U.S. economy, together with the increase in wages in the short term, have surely reduced the risk of a recession this year. However, there is a simultaneous risk that the

U.S. monetary authority may have to increase interest rates even more than the markets have been anticipating. There are two reasons for this: one is related to the uncertainty of the inflation projections in that economy, and the other is derived from the monetary authorities' commitment to controlling inflation.

In Colombia, the economy is more vulnerable due to a higher fiscal deficit and the effects of changes in the economic policy of developed countries. To this, we must add two other factors of uncertainty: the scope of the policies that the National Government will implement and the effect that the tax reform may have on the country's growth.

To manage these risks, we measure, monitor and control the risk associated with the factors that could affect investments abroad, which includes analysis on the deterioration of macroeconomic, political and legal variables in different countries that are recipients of the Bank's investment. This analysis involves the participation of the Bank's economic studies, corporate credit and legal areas, which escalate the potential risk to the governing bodies, in an attempt to mitigate exposure to geopolitical risks and international exposure to financial contagion.

Additionally, our area of economic studies periodically analyzes international economic policies and reports to the Senior Management and the Board of Directors on the main events that have occurred in the financial markets, as well as about local and international macroeconomic perspectives, including projection models. Likewise, the risk committees and our business areas continue to monitor the behavior of our clients with regards to savings and payment and the behavior of the sectors in which they operate in order to generate the action plans that are required.

## Cyber conflict risk

This risk is caused by new and uncertain cyber attacks derived from international uncertainties and the growth of global, regional and local political instability. This instability establishes a new scenario of tensions that affect the dynamics of organizations. At the local level, we have seen that this risk has been increasing mainly due to internal conflicts and social protests, capable of creating scenarios of confusion, deception and disinformation that can affect organizations, mainly those that make up the critical cybernetic infrastructure of the countries and within which the Bank is part. The materialization of this type of attack brings serious consequences at the level of the operation, the availability of computer systems, service channels, and leakage or improper access to sensitive Bank information.

In the same way, this risk of cyber conflicts can affect public or private sector entities commercially related to the Bank (such as affiliates, subsidiaries, business partners, suppliers and other stakeholders), exposing their data and financial assets to scenarios of unavailability, loss or non-consensual transfers. To counteract this, the Bank has strengthened our security mechanisms in order to mitigate the occurrence of this type of attack that may affect our corporate clients.

The main impacts that could be generated by the materialization of the risk, which are as follows:

-   Adverse e/ffects on the brand (reputational risk).
-   Possible depreciation of the value of intellectual property.
-   Higher operational expenses for the prevention of future attacks, containment and recovery against materialized threats.
-   Possible impact on premiums to insure against future events.
-   Regulatory sanctions and /fines for regulatory noncompliance.
-   Materialization of technological fraud towards our clients.
-   Commitment of sensitive information.

To mitigate this risk, we continue strengthening the strategy, deepening and developing different roles in the organization in order to prevent, protect, detect and recover from any event that we are forced to face in a timely manner. We have also adopted and implemented new procedures, methodologies and tools that allow us to manage this type of risk.

During 2022, we undertook the following efforts to manage this risk:

-   Adoption of best practices in Cybersecurity and Information Security to improve the processes that support the strategy.
-   Attention and response to the di/fferent requirements of regulatory entities in aspects concerning Information Security and Cybersecurity with remarkable management.

'A. National Standards: To determine the independence of the members of the Board of Directors, Davivienda S.A. accepts the criteria established in article 44 of law 964 of 2005, namely: 'independent shall be understood as a person who in no case is:

- 1. Employee or o/fficer of the Banco de la Republica or of any of its a/ffiliates, subsidiaries or controlling companies, including those persons who have had such capacity during the year immediately prior to the appointment, except in the case of the re-election of an independent person.
- 2. Shareholders who directly or by virtue of an agreement lead, guide or control the majority of the voting rights of the organization or who determine the majority composition of the administrative, management or control bodies of the organization.
- 3. Partner or employee of associations or companies that provide advisory or consulting services to the Banco de la Republica or to the companies that belong to the same economic group of which they are part, when the income for such a concept represents for them twenty percent (20%) or more of their operational income.
- 4. Employee or director of a foundation, association or corporation that receives important donations from the Banco de la Republica. Signi/ficant donations are considered to be those that represent more than twenty percent (20%) of the total donations received by the respective institution.
- 5. Administrator of an entity in whose board of directors a legal representative of the Banco de la Republica participates.
- 6. A person who receives from the Banco de la Republica any remuneration other than fees as a member of the board of directors, the auditing committee or any other committee created by the board of directors.

## President of the Board of Directors

The President of the Board of Directors is Mr. Carlos Guillermo Arango Uribe . The Chairman of the Board of Directors does not hold any administrative position in the company. In accordance with Article 42 of the Bank's Bylaws and Article 18 of the Regulations of the Board of Directors, the president of the Board of Directors of the company has the following responsibilities.

##   According to the bylaws

- a. To chair the meetings of the Board of Directors and to manage the meeting discussions.
- b. To ensure the execution of the resolutions of the Board of Directors and to follow up on their assignments and decisions.
- c. To monitor the active participation of the members of the Board of Directors.
- d. To lead the annual evaluation process of the Board of Directors and the Committees, except for his own evaluation.

##   According to the Board of Directors Regulations

- a. To chair the meetings of the Board of Directors.
- b. To submit to the Board the proposals they deem appropriate for the proper functioning of the Bank and, especially, those corresponding to the operation of the Board itself and other corporate bodies, whether prepared by the Bank itself or by another member of the Board.
- c. To make the necessary recommendations to the Board of Directors on issues related to good Corporate Governance.

The foregoing, without prejudice to the responsibilities established in the regulations in force.

In accordance with our Conflict of Interest, Use of Privileged Information and Related Parties Manual, related parties are defined as:

' natural person, legal person or investment vehicle that presents a situation of control or subordination with respect to a CFB entity in a direct or indirect manner, or that belongs to the Bolivar Business Group; capital participants or beneficial owners that own ten percent (10%) or more of the shareholding of any entity of the Bolivar Financial Conglomerate (CFB); legal entities in which any entity of the CFB is the beneficial owner of ten percent (10%) or more of the corporate shareholding; legal entities that are subordinate to any of the capital participants or beneficial owners of 10% or more of the shareholding in any entity of the CFB; administrators of the Companies that are members of Grupo Empresarial Bolívar; companies in which an administrator of Grupo Bolívar S. ## TECHNOLOGY

The technological strategy is a key factor for the sustainable success of any organization, since it implies the constant modernization of systems and processes. In this sense, we invest in state-of-the-art technologies, such as the cloud, automation and analytics. They allow us to scale our operations and reduce costs in an efficient manner, offering faster, more personalized and secure services. We are also adopting agile methodologies and DevOps to improve collaboration and speed in the development and implementation of technology projects.

## Davivienda, a disruptive technology player

We are leaders in the adoption of digital and disruptive trends. Therefore, we continue to explore new technologies such as blockchain, internet of things, artificial intelligence, big data, cloud computing, among others, in order to find innovative ways to solve traditional operations and transactions, as well as to build new products and services. In this regard, some of the projects we are executing include the development of an ecosystem that allows us to offer money transfers with other financial institutions, the issuance of private bonds, and friendly and reliable services that allow customers to manage their products from their mobile devices.

## Evolution towards the cloud and implementation of ecosystems with digital talent

As a fundamental element of our digital transformation, and as part of our Banking as a Service and Open Banking strategy, we have trained more than 450 employees in cloud

technologies. This has allowed us to connect with more than 40 allies. We have also implemented new functionalities in our core accounts. That has facilitated the digital transformation of services and has allowed the execution of our FinOps strategy for cost management and optimization. As a result, we have been able to reduce our annual cloud consumption expenditure by 13%.

In addition, we have initiated the formation of our internal digital factory to accelerate the construction of digital assets and strengthen our service and product offerings. As a result, we have implemented 67 new initiatives. This translates into an increase of 21% compared to the previous year. All this has generated an efficiency of COP 1.4 billion and has allowed more than 80% of our clients to link using our digital channels.

## Evolution of the analytical ecosystem

Over the past year, our bank has made significant progress in modernizing our data analytics technology. This has allowed us to significantly improve our efficiency and availability. We have migrated to cloud-native platforms, which has given us greater flexibility and scalability. In addition to that, we have deepened our use of analytics to develop specific solutions to improve the effectiveness of our marketing campaigns, reduce credit risk and detect potential fraud.

We have also implemented solutions to improve operational and accounting reconciliation and consolidation, which has allowed us to have a more complete and accurate view of our business.

## We continue to modernize our systems

We are strategically and consistently undertaking the modernization of our technology. This involves reducing obsolescence and adopting a new-generation technology stack. However, this transformation brings along significant challenges, such as the integration of different systems and computing platforms.

During the past year, we managed to make significant progress in our disaster recovery strategy. In this regard, we moved our contingency data center to the city of Medellin. That has given us greater capacity and geographic diversity to respond to events that could affect our operations. We also relocated part of our team to operate from that city. Thanks to these efforts, we have increased the maturity of our resilience strategy and are committed to continue strengthening our capabilities to offer our customers the best possible quality of service in any situation.

## Secure customers and transactions

Our goal is to stay one step ahead in fraud detection and prevention, and to do so, we face increasingly sophisticated challenges. In this regard, the implementation of advanced detection systems in digital and face-to-face channels allows us to respond effectively to these threats, while providing us with a competitive advantage by protecting the Bank's

assets and reducing the risk of losses caused by third parties. We are committed to continue improving our capabilities and we are confident that these efforts will enable us to provide a safer and more reliable service to our customers.

## At Davivienda, we understand the growing importance of data security and cybersecurity

That is why we have implemented a new cybersecurity operations model. This model includes capabilities for continuous verification of the validity and strength of our controls to deal with increasingly sophisticated cyberpunks. In addition to that, we are using real-time data analytics to identify advanced threats (threat hunting) and we employ artificial intelligence to predict which of these threats represent a real risk.

During 2022, we executed cybersecurity projects that have adopted exponential technologies, such as hyper-automation and threat identification based on behavioral analysis. All this has allowed us to make security an essential and organic component of our services. Thanks to these advances, Davivienda is always one step ahead in the detection and prevention of cyber threats, guaranteeing the security and privacy of our clients' and the organization's information.

## Evolution of tools to provide customer support

## COLOMBIA 39

The global economy did not grow as expected in 2022. The World Bank forecast early in 2022 expected the world economy to grow at a 4.1% annual rate. However, a year later, its growth estimate was reduced to 2.9% 40 . Nevertheless, despite this downward adjustment for the global economy, growth estimates for Latin America increased from 2.6% at the beginning of the year to 3.6%. Global growth projections deteriorated because inflation rose more than expected, prompting tighter monetary policies in most countries around the world. The adverse effect of the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the resulting sanctions have also played a significant role.

Oil prices continued to rebound throughout the year, due to global economic growth but, above all, to a less accommodating policy by OPEC countries and as a consequence of the crude oil shortage generated by the international conflict. On average, Brent benchmark crude oil prices reached USD 92.4 per barrel, well above the figure recorded in 2021 (USD 70.8), and significantly higher than the 2020 price (USD 41.9) 41 .

## FISCAL POLICY

Based on the most recent figures released by the Ministry of Finance, it is estimated that the fiscal deficit of the Colombian National Government amounted to 5.5% of the GDP in 2022, lower than the 7.1% figure recorded in 2021. Revenues totaled COP 238.6 trillion, achieving an increase of 24.2% compared to the previous year. ## EXCHANGE RATE

In 2022, Latin American currencies were subject to substantial pressure exerted by several factors, including: the appreciation of the USD internationally and worsening fiscal conditions in certain countries. Political events also played an important role in a number of countries, such as the results of the referendum on the new constitution in Chile and the election of President Lula for the third time in Brazil.

The Colombian currency depreciated sharply in 2022, by 20.8%, from 3,981.2 COP per 1 USD at the beginning of the year to COP 4,810.2 on the last day. This is attributable to an increased country risk, as well as to the strong appreciation of the USD worldwide following interest rate hikes in the United States. 10-year CDS levels averaged 343 points over the year, considerably higher than the 202 points recorded the previous year. Additionally, increased country risk was associated, among other factors, with the uncertainty surrounding the policies of the new administration; the risk premium decreased only at the end of the year, following the approval of the tax reform and a decrease in global risk aversion.

Even though in 2022 there was a net inflow of foreign portfolio investment amounting to approximately 1,749 million USD, portfolio capital outflows from Colombian investors abroad amounted to 864 million USD. ## ASSETS ANALYSIS AND STRUCTURE

At the end of the year, assets totaled COP 184.1 trillion, growing by 20.6% compared to 2021, mainly driven by gross loans, which grew by COP 26.2 trillion (22.1% annual increase), mainly due to the behavior in the commercial and consumer portfolios, which grew by 20.1% and 28.2%, respectively. Our mortgage portfolio grew by 18.5% over the year. As of December 2022, gross loans accounted for 78.6% of the Bank's total Assets.

Cash and interbank funds amounted to COP 16.3 trillion, growing by 5.6%, mainly in Central America, as the exchange rate effect led to a COP 3 trillion increase. Our investment portfolio grew by 17.4%, explained by the increased valuation of our debt investment portfolio in Colombia and the exchange rate effect in Central America.

Commercial loans grew by 20.1%, mainly explained by corporate demand. The exchange rate effect had a significant impact, accounting for 7.2 percentage points of yearly growth.

Consumer loans increased by 28.2%, mainly due to demand for unsecured personal loans, credit cards, and payroll loans throughout the year.

The mortgage portfolio grew by 22.1%, mainly explained by traditional mortgages, low-income housing, and residential leasing, particularly in Colombia, aligned with sector dynamics and Government subsidy programs.

As of December 2022, 90-days PDL closed at 3.13%, 22 basis points lower than the previous year, in line with portfolio growth, improved customer payment behavior, and write-offs made throughout the year.

The PDL ratio for the commercial portfolio decreased by 77 basis points over the year, reflecting improved customer payment behavior and, to a lower extent, write-offs throughout the year.

The PDL ratio for the consumer portfolio increased by 104 basis points over the year, as high interest rates affected customer payment capacity, and the change in this portfolio's risk profile in Colombia.

## SITUACIÓN DE LIQUIDEZ

Both Banco Davivienda and its subsidiaries experienced a number of liquidity management challenges in 2022. Amid a context marked by rising global inflation and a generalized contractionary monetary policy to control it, funding costs increased becoming difficult to obtain across all economies. In Colombia specifically, this was exacerbated by the competition in raising term funds to comply with the new long-term liquidity indicator NSFR (CFEN).

These conditions reduced excess liquidity, leading to various measures being adopted to rebuild target liquidity levels, including: increasing term deposits in stable segments, individuals, and companies; and securing structural funding through long term loans.

This situation did not represent a material issue for any of our companies, throughout the year Davienda and all of its subsidiaries complied sufficiently with regulatory short and long term liquidity ratios.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

On average, the Bank maintained liquid assets totaling 12.7 trillion COP, allowing it to meet liquidity needs by 1.5 times in a 30-day horizon, aligned with the regulatory methodology defined by the Financial Superintendence of Colombia. On the other hand, the Net Stable Funding Ratio (CFEN), designed to ensure that entities have sufficient stable funding to support their long-term assets, averaged 103.7% throughout the year, showing an average 3.3 trillion COP positive gap.

Additionally, all subsidiaries maintained an adequate and stable liquidity position throughout the year, thereby complying proficiently with both internal and regulatory indicators.

## INCOME STATEMENT

As of December 2022, the Bank's consolidated profits totaled COP 1.62 trillion, growing by 28.1% over the previous year. 2022 was marked by a number of challenges for the Bank's liquidity management:

- � Widespread interest rate hikes around the world caused an increase in funding costs which in turn made it more di/fficult to obtain. Particularly in Colombia, the 900 basis point interest rate increase by the Central Bank, together with increased competition in the /financial sector to obtain term funding in order to comply with the new long term liquidity indicator, NSFR (CFEN).
- � The environment characterized by political uncertainty and seemingly entrenched in/flation expectations, led to a low investor appetite towards the bond market.
- � Accelerated growth in the consumer portfolio during the /first half of the year

These conditions exerted pressure on both short and long term liquidity ratios. Consequently, various measures were adopted to rebuild target liquidity levels, such as increasing term deposits in stable segments, individuals, and companies; and securing structural funding through loans granted by multilateral banks.

However, this situation did not represent a material issue for the Bank, we complied sufficiently with all regulatory liquidity requirements, which were sufficiently fulfilled throughout 2022. For Banco Davivienda, the Liquidity Risk Indicator-IRL, which measures the amount of liquid assets versus liquidity needs in a 30-day horizon, exceeded liquidity needs by an average of 146 times. The Colombian economy performed relatively positive in terms of growth in the course of 2022. ## INTRODUCTION

Our actions are shaped by our higher purpose: enriching life with integrity . We enrich the lives of people and the planet by leveraging the transformative power of our business models, while securing our long-term presence, with accountability towards our stakeholders and environmental awareness, amidst a growing number of challenges affecting the financial industry. We conducted a materiality review in both 2021 and 2022, identifying 8 material issues that address the ESG dimensions of our strategy. Climate change stands out as the most relevant.

We are committed to sustainable development and conceive crises as opportunities to shatter paradigms and further take on the challenges associated with climate change faced by industries and the financial sector. We are committed to reducing CO 2 emissions throughout our operations, as well as in our lending practices by funding projects and activities aimed at mitigating and adapting to climate change, and by adequately managing the potential negative impacts of climate change. We follow global best practices to address key issues for our organization and our stakeholders.

<!-- image -->

## Climate change

is the most important material subject within the ESG matters of our strategy.

Climate change is highly relevant in our industry, as it may have direct financial consequences. It is also the source of important conversations around climate risks, whether physical or transition, prompting rapid strategic business decisions and moving funds towards activities aimed at transitioning to a low-carbon economy. Therefore, we adhered to the TCFD in 2020, submitted our first report in 2021 and are now sharing our second report, highlighting our progress in climate management. We are committed to actions geared towards meeting global needs in the years to come.

Davivienda strives to manage climate change by reducing water and energy consumption, mitigating our carbon footprint, investing in green building projects, deploying non-conventional renewable energy (NCRE) projects, adopting a circular economy approach, and promoting sustainability among our personnel. As part of the suite of products and services offered to our customers, since 2014 we have designed lines of credit with environmental benefits aimed at promoting climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts, raising awareness, and yielding positive business outcomes.

## We strive to meet global standards and adopt best practices on climate change management .

Consequently, since 2014 we have been reporting our climate performance via the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) and we are part of the Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI). Furthermore, in 2015 we were also included in the S&P Sustainability Yearbook, which acknowledges the top 15% companies with the best sustainability practices in the world.

We ratified our responsibilities on climate change in 2020, pledging to implement the recommendations issued by the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) for identifying, managing and disclosing the opportunities, risks and financial impacts derived from climate change.

As part of these efforts, we joined the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF) in 2022 to measure financed emissions, and the Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI), designed to promote responsible investment to build sustainable markets for a healthier and more prosperous world.

## CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AND SUSTAINABILITY COMMITTEE

In 2021, the Board of Directors consolidated corporate governance and sustainability issues into a single committee, with an integrated ESG business perspective.

## Functions of the Committee

In addition to supporting the Board of Directors, its objective is to oversee, review, and implement policies, guidelines, and procedures related to best corporate governance practices and sustainability standards, observing national and international measures and standards, as well as voluntary agreements submitted to the Board of Directors for approval.

The Committee is composed of 5 permanent members: a member of the Board of Directors, the President of the Bank, the Executive Vice President of Risk, the Executive Vice President of Retail Banking and Markets, and the Legal Counsel Vice President. The Vice President of Credit Risk and the Director of Sustainability are permanent guests. The meetings are held on a quarterly basis.

## CORPORATE RISK COMMITTEE

It supports the Board of Directors and oversees the operation of the Comprehensive Risk Management System (SIAR), formerly ERM (Enterprise Risk Management), established for the Bank and its subsidiaries. The Committee is composed of 3 members of the Board of Directors and meets 4 times a year or whenever one of its members deems it convenient.

## Functions of the Committee

Makes sure that risk systems operate with synchronicity and in an integrated fashion across the organization; ensures that the organization stays within its established risk appetite; and fosters a risk management culture. Specifically for climate change risk, the Committee followsup on the 5-year plan,and oversees how climate risks are managed based on the scopes. Furthermore, it works on continuous improvement and defines and fine-tunes risk appetites.

## RISKS ARISING FROM CLIMATE CHANGE

Identifying and assessing climate change risks, whether classified as physical or transition, falls within the Environmental and Social Risk Management System (SARAS) process, whereby eligibility criteria are stipulated for granting green loans in the commercial and retail banking segments.

## TRANSITION RISKS

Risks associated with the transition to a low-carbon economy stemming from regulatory changes, disruptive technologies, and evolving market trends, as well as other factors involved in combating climate change.

## A Regulatory and Legal Risks

Risks arising from policies designed to transform production models; these risks affect mostly carbon-intensive sectors.

## A Technological Risks

Risks derived from the need to implement technologies to transform production models, considering that some of these technologies have not been fully tested; or risks derived from the need to implement new, high-cost technologies.

## A Market Risks

Risks related to changes in consumer demand as they change their perception towards activities or products that they regard as CO/two.denominator-intensive, or due to the rising cost of raw materials.

## A Reputational Risk

Risk associated with changing customer or public perceptions of how an organization is contributing to or undermining the transition to a low-carbon economy.

## RISK MANAGEMENT

The purpose of our Integrated Risk Management System (SIAR) , formerly ERM (Enterprise Risk Management), is to enable the Bank to achieve its strategic objectives, grounded on a risk management approach that fosters business growth and maximizes opportunities founded on risk management, administration, and control.

The macro processes or business lines that play a major role in the strategy or that lead to greater exposure to risks must be supported by specialized risk areas, which are in charge of assessing the effectiveness of risk management. This joint analysis conducted on strategies, business units, and implicit risks underscores how each unit involves various dimensions of risk and operational complexities.

Each business cycle involves different dimensions, which are managed by specialized teams through risk verticals, responsible for comprehensively assessing strategic, technical, and operational risks. Similarly, across-the-board risk teams evaluate common risks, regardless of their origin, arising from business units underlying processes.

Since 2021, climate change risk was added across-theboard to our overall risk management framework, in conjunction with the environmental and social risk management approach introduced in 2011, so as to integrate it into each of the main verticals.

## SCENARIO ANALYSIS FOR PHYSICAL RISKS

Scenario analysis enables a forward-looking perspective consistent with increased climate-related physical risks and allows us to weigh the financial implications of a range of assumptions to inform decisions on policy, criteria, and financial planning.

To fine-tune our scenario analysis for physical risks in 2022, we focused on integrating, through a pilot exercise, data from WorldClim, creating analytical layers for Colombia.

Worldclim.org data is publicly available, showing results from all models used to build climate change maps for each of the RCPs (Representative Concentration Pathway), depicting various CO/two.denominator concentration scenarios (RCP 2.6, RCP 4.5, RCP 7.0 and RCP 8.5) ranging from the year 2021 to the year 2100.

By generating results based on global model data available in WorldClim, we were able to start a comparative analysis against the results of the pilot project carried out in 2021 based on Ideam's Third Communication. This comparison enriched our methodology and helped us to design our own management model, more accurate and with more recent data for the RCPs.

The results derived from the WorldClim models enabled us to identify and prioritize the regions with the greatest temperature and rainfall fluctuations, based on historical averages in Colombia. Subsequently, we analyzed existing loans in these areas to ascertain the amount and percentage of loans that could be exposed to greater climate change events in the long term as well as the economic activities that could suffer the greatest impact due to climate change.

This work stems from collaboration with the innovation team of Seguros Bolivar, especially to georeference the bank's portfolios and update the flood and landslide hazard layers.

## MEASUREMENT OF FINANCED EMISSIONS

We joined PCAF (Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials) at the end of 2022 with the purpose of implementing a globally recognized methodology to measure the carbon emissions derived from our financing or investments, as these may be the most significant part of our emissions inventory, thereby completing our carbon footprint measurement. Measuring financed emissions is key to setting climate action targets, perform better and align with the Paris Agreement. Current target setting initiatives, such as Science Based Targets, rely on baseline calculation for implementation.

Our risk appetite framework covers a number of areas, such as risk threshold, stakeholders, objectives, and risk metrics. We thereby determine the top layer of the risk appetite framework, which must be articulated with specific metrics for each line of business and/or type of risk, in conjunction with those aspects defined in the organization's strategic plan. We thus bridge organizational strategic development and the quest for profitability with desired or tolerated levels of risk for the organization.

We moved forward in environmental, social and climate change risk management, improving and updating our environmental risk appetite, using exclusion lists and portfolio thresholds, including metrics for industries most sensitive to climate change risks, as well as business growth approaches to seize opportunities to finance projects focused on climate change adaptation and mitigation.

In 2022, we strengthened our circular economy strategy with actions focused on raw materials, design, production, reuse, repair, collection, recycling, and waste management.

## A Eco-Design

We strive to minimize negative environmental impacts by implementing a responsible approach to raw materials, design and production. We delivered 93 thousand credit cards made from 100% recycled PVC from different industries such as packaging, printing, and the automotive industry. In addition, our emblematic Casita Roja piggy bank is now produced with post-consumer recycled (PCR) plastic.

## A Collection

We compiled disused assets and goods for reuse. We participated in the toner reverse logistics program with Lexmark, whereby we properly disposed of 1,295 toner cartridges under a zero landfill and zero incineration policy .
