We refurbished 3.7 tons of furniture such as chairs, tables and others, which we reused in our headquarters and branches. We also donated 50 chairs to our Cultivarte location in Barranquilla, sold 3,319 assets to our employees and managed nearly 129 tons of materials from disused furniture.

## INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY / LIST OF PATENTS, TRADEMARKS, LICENSES, FRANCHISES, AND OTHER COPYRIGHTS

Banco Davivienda complies with all applicable regulations governing intellectual property and maintains a structural system for these purposes. This includes special policies in place for IP assets, personnel in charge of managing related processes and enforcing policies, permanent controls, and monitoring processes designed to provide legal safeguards when launching new products and services, in addition to permanent oversight and monitoring systems covering 15 countries.

Currently, Banco Davivienda and its Colombian subsidiaries hold an intellectual property portfolio of 448 trademarks (distinctive signs) registered or filed with the Superintendence of Industry and Commerce as the competent National Industrial Property Bureau. Davivienda®, Daviplata® and Casita Roja de Davivienda® trademarks are acknowledged as 'notorious' trademarks. These trademarks are material for carrying out the Company's corporate purpose and, hence have been renewed in 2022, thereby benefiting from global

special protection mechanisms, enforceable even in jurisdictions where the Bank does not operate.

Davivienda has filed 5 patent applications to date in Colombia.

Davivienda holds five copyright registrations (deposits) for its tangible assets with the Colombian National Copyright Directorate (DNDA).

Davivienda holds 1,126 registrations or pending applications: 448 in Colombia and 678 in other countries.

Davivienda's main brands are also protected in every country where the Bank operates directly. Additionally, Davivienda is protected by preventive registrations in countries where it does not operate directly, but that are strategically relevant internationally, enabling potential future expansions at any time.

Davivienda operates a sound trademark oversight system that enables the Bank to discover potentially infringing trademarks and to file infringement actions or administrative defense actions, in 15 countries in the Americas.

## BANCO DAVIVIENDA'S FORESEEABLE EVOLUTION

We will continue working towards achieving our shared Higher Purpose as a business group, playing a leading role in strengthening economic growth across the countries we serve. Accordingly, our growth projections are aligned with a favorable macroeconomic outlook for our business operations.

To accomplish our goals, customers will remain at the core of our management model, as we deliver new experiences through reliable, straightforward, and user-friendly solutions.

We will continue moving forward towards achieving our goals and on our transformation journey, delivering value to all of our stakeholders, grounded on effective risk management, innovation, strategic partnerships, analytical capabilities, exponential technologies, and by attracting and training the best talent for a digital world.

## Assessment of Impairment of Loan Portfolio under IFRS 9 (see notes 6, 10.3.1.4, 12.5.1 and 12.5.4 to the consolidated financial statements)

## Key Audit Matter

## How it was addressed in the audit

The Group periodically reviews the credit risk exposure of its loan portfolio. Such determination is one of the most significant and complex estimates in the preparation of the accompanying consolidated financial statements, due to the high degree of judgment involved in the development of models to determine impairment based on an expected loss approach required by IFRS 9. The value of the loan portfolio and its respective impairment as of December 31, 2022 is $144,787,324 million and $6,318,527 million, respectively.

I considered the assessment of loan portfolio impairment as a key audit matter because it involves significant measurement complexity that required judgment, knowledge and experience in the industry particularly in relation to (1) the evaluation of the methodologies used, including the methodology for estimating loss given default; (2) the probability of loss given default and its key factors and assumptions; (3) the loan grading and qualitative factors that are incorporated within the internal model variables established by the Group; and (4) the estimated credit risk impairment calculations for the entire loan portfolio.

My audit procedures for assessing the adequacy of credit risk impairment included, among others, the following:

- · Engagement of professionals with experience and expertise in credit risk assessment and information technology to evaluate certain internal controls related to the Group's process for determining loan portfolio impairment. This included controls related to (1) validation of the models that determine the probability of loss, LGD and exposure at default, (2) the Group's monitoring of the determination of portfolio impairment (3) information technology controls over the input data to the models that determine credit impairment, as well as related calculations; (4) the assessment to identify whether there was a significant change in credit risk; (5) the evaluation of macroeconomic variables and weighted scenarios used in the models for the determination of credit portfolio impairment; and (6) the verification of controls related to the evaluation of individually analyzed trade receivables and write-offs.
- · Professionals with expertise in credit risk assessment and information technology assisted me in (1) evaluating the methodologies and key data used to determine the probability of loss, loss severity and exposure at default and the parameters produced by the models; (2) evaluating the macroeconomic variables and weighted probability scenarios used in the internal models including consideration of alternative data for certain variables; (3) recalculating the expected loss model and its related data; and (4) evaluating the

## Auditors' responsibilities for the audit of the consolidated financial statements

My objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements taken are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an audit report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance means a high level of assurance but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with ISAs will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise due to fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken based on these consolidated financial statements.

As part of an audit conducted in accordance with ISAs, I exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism during the audit. I also:

-  Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one arising from error, because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.
-  Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances.
-  Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by management.
-  Conclude on the appropriateness of management's use of the going concern assumption and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether or not a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may indicate significant doubt about the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that a material uncertainty exists, I should draw attention in my report to the disclosure that describes this situation in the consolidated financial statements or, if this disclosure is inadequate, I should modify my opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of my report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to operate as a going concern.
-  Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements present the underlying transactions and events so as to achieve a fair presentation.

## Key Audit Matter

## How it was addressed in the audit

As of December 31, 2022, the Bank recorded an additional general provision for consumer loan portfolio of $186,000 million, approved by the Board of Directors, which was created to cover the credit risk derived from the potential affectation of the debtors' payment capacity in a context of economic slowdown and inflation, in compliance with the provisions of the third instruction of External Circular 026 of 2022 of the Superintendency of Finance of Colombia.

I considered the additional general allowance for consumer loan portfolio as a key audit matter, because its estimation required significant judgment, knowledge of the clients and experience in its industry, especially in relation to: (1) the definition of the methodology used, (2) the prospective estimation of the potential impairment in the consumer loan portfolio associated with the possible increase in the levels of default of debtors in the event of changes in the macroeconomic context, and the potential use of

My audit procedures for evaluating the additional general allowance for consumer credit risk included, but were not limited to, the following:

-  Involvement of professionals with experience and knowledge in credit risk assessment and information technology, to evaluate certain internal controls related to the Bank's process for the determination of the additional general allowance for the consumer loan portfolio based on the instructions of the Superintendencia Financiera de Colombia. This included controls related to: (1) approvals and follow-up by the Board of Directors of the methodology for the estimation of the additional general allowance for the consumer loan portfolio; (2) the Bank's monitoring of changes in the risk of the consumer loan portfolio customers; (3) information technology controls over the input data to the models that determine the additional general allowance for consumer loans, as well as the related calculations; and (4) the evaluation of the macroeconomic variables considered for the estimation of the additional general

contingent quotas for the impact on income in the face of the economic slowdown and (3) the segmentation of customers considering their credit risk.

- 1º) If the Society's management performance is in conformity with the bylaws and the instructions or decisions of the Sole Shareholder ' s Meeting, and
- 3) If there are and are adequate the measures of internal control, maintenance and custody of the Society's assets or third parties' assets in its pos session.

## Responsibility of Management

The Company's management is responsible for compliance with the bylaws and the decisions of the Shareholders' Meeting and for designing, implementing and maintaining adequate internal control  measures,  which  include  the  risk  management  and  customer  service  systems implemented Liquidity Risk Management System (SARL), Market Risk Management System (SARM),  Operational  Risk  Management  System  (SARO),  Credit  Risk  Management  System (SARC), Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing Risk Management System (SARLAFT) and Financial Customer Service System (SAC), Credit Risk Management System (SARC), Asset Laundering and  Financing of Terrorism Risk Management System (SARLAFT) and Financial Consumer  Service  System  (SAC),  and  the  conservation  and  custody  measures  of  the Company's  assets  or  those  of  third  parties  in  its  possession,  in  accordance  with  the requirements of Part  1, Title 1, Chapter IV and Part III, Title V, Chapter I of the Basic Legal Circular of the Superintendency of Finance of Colombia.

## Statutory Auditor's responsibility

My responsibility is to examine if Society's management performance is in conformity with the bylaws and the instructions or decisions of the Sole Shareholder ' s Meeting, if there are and are adequate measures of internal control, maintenance and custody of the Society's assets or third parties' assets in its possession and to report as an independent reasonable assurance conclusion based on the evidence obtained. ## REPORT ON THE RESULTS OF THE EVALUATION CONDUCTED ON INTERNAL CONTROL SYSTEMS AND PROCEDURES FOR CONTROL AND DISCLOSURE OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION

## December 2022

Banco Davivienda S.A. relies on policies and procedures required to operate its Internal Control System (ICS) in accordance with the current regulation.

Currently, control standards are applied to the Bank's operations, which are executed and monitored in each of the organizational processes. These standards are periodically evaluated by the Vice Presidency of Internal Audit and other control bodies.

Banco Davivienda S.A.'s ICS features the following characteristics:

- ● To encourage and maintain an adequate control environment built upon organizational culture, raising awareness among employees.
- ● To continuously strengthen the established risk management systems, supporting operations by establishing objectives, identifying incidents, assessing them, and responding to risks.
- ● Define and implement control activities and procedures required to manage risks; periodically assess how such activities and procedures are performing and formulate mitigation plans accordingly to the evaluated risks.
- ● Take appropriate actions aimed at protecting, storing, accessing, preserving, safeguarding, and disclosing information, ensuring data reliability, integrity and availability; effectively communicating key information to relevant parties and stakeholders.
- ● Set and enforce policies and procedures aimed at ensuring continuous monitoring and oversight by both management and upper management.

To verify the effectiveness of the ICS, the Bank is supported by the Audit Vice-presidency and the Risk Management areas who, according to the three lines of defense scheme, carry out evaluation and monitoring; likewise, they identify the areas that execute internal control from the First Line. The above, in the following way:

First Line: Includes those who are responsible for processes, who are in charge of designing, executing, and overseeing controls that mitigate risks associated with financial reporting.

The main duties of the First Line are: designing, executing, and overseeing controls related to identifying, measuring, and disclosing financial information. These controls are applied throughout the entire process, starting from initial transactions to their preparation, consolidation, and disclosure through the various institutional channels and control bodies.

These processes are formally documented and there are well-defined and effective execution and oversight controls in place to provide reasonable assurance in terms of financial reporting risk mitigation.

<!-- image -->

Second Line: Risk areas monitor the Entity's controls under a second-line approach. This includes key financial reporting controls, namely those designed to ensure the proper recording, processing, and disclosure of financial information.

Various methodologies are used to monitor these controls, such as:

- ● Evaluation of controls in conjunction with those responsible for processes (first line).
- ● Focused and prioritized monitoring to measure the reasonableness and effectiveness of controls.

Based on these results, identified opportunities for improvement are conveyed to those in charge of processes, improvement actions are defined, and control ratings are updated, if required.

Third Line: The Bank's Audit Vice-presidency assesses the Internal Control System to determine if it is reasonable to assure that it is effective, encompassing financial reporting matters (Accounting Management).

The Internal Audit Vice-presidency independently and objectively assesses risk management, internal control, and corporate governance. Based on its findings, it shares recommendations aimed at improving processes and operations. Key financial reporting controls are embedded in these evaluations. The assessments in 2022 were conducted under the approved planning, following a risk level prioritization exercise for the various processes within the Bank, guided by the Strategy Map and regulatory and legal obligations. No material deficiencies were identified upon revision of financial reporting related processes.

Internal Audit followed up on the action plans defined by those responsible for processes, who followed the recommendations made and continue to do so; similarly, the Audit Committee and additional Corporate Governance bodies monitored the status of implementation and effectiveness of such plans, thereby contributing towards achieving our mission to properly present and disclose financial information.

As a result of the activities conducted by the three defined lines, no significant deficiencies were detected that would have prevented the recognition, measurement, and disclosure of the financial information.
